title: 106_hr4744
content: The Act may be cited as the "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000". Congress finds that Federal regulations have improved the quality of life for the American public, but uncontrolled increases in regulatory costs and lost opportunities for better regulation should not continue. The legislative branch must ensure that laws passed by Congress are properly implemented by the executive branch, requiring accurate and reliable information for efficient, effective, and fair implementation. The Congress requires accurate and reliable information for efficient, effective, and fair implementation of laws. The purposes of this Act are to increase transparency in regulatory decisions, promote congressional oversight, and enhance accountability to the people. The Act aims to increase transparency in regulatory decisions, promote congressional oversight, and enhance accountability to the people by defining key terms. The Act defines key terms such as "agency" and "economically significant rule" to increase transparency in regulatory decisions and promote congressional oversight. The Act defines key terms such as "agency" and "economically significant rule" to increase transparency in regulatory decisions and promote congressional oversight. An "independent evaluation" involves a substantive review of an agency's data, methodology, and assumptions used in developing economically significant rules. This evaluation includes an analysis of strengths and weaknesses that impact the conclusions reached. The independent evaluation involves reviewing an agency's data, methodology, and assumptions for economically significant rules. It analyzes strengths and weaknesses that impact conclusions reached in the rulemaking process. SEC. 4. REPORT ON RULES. When an agency publishes an economically significant rule, a committee member can request the Comptroller General to review it. The Comptroller General must submit a report on the rule to the relevant committees in Congress within 180 days of the request. The Comptroller General must submit an independent evaluation of economically significant rules to relevant committees in Congress within 180 days of a committee member's request. The independent evaluation by the Comptroller General of economically significant rules includes assessing potential benefits and costs, identifying beneficiaries and those bearing costs. The evaluation of regulatory impact analysis, federalism assessment, or other agency-prepared assessments includes identifying costs, exploring alternative cost-effective approaches, and explaining reasons for not adopting alternatives. The agency must provide a summary of the evaluation of regulatory impact analysis, federalism assessment, or other assessments prepared for the economically significant rule, including any changes made in the final rule. The Comptroller General, in collaboration with Senate and House leaders, will establish procedures to prioritize and report on requests for review of proposed and interim rules. Agencies must cooperate with the Comptroller General. The Comptroller General will establish procedures to prioritize and report on requests for review of rules, and agencies must cooperate with the Comptroller General. Nothing in this Act is intended to expand or limit the authority of the General Accounting Office. Authorization of appropriations for the General Accounting Office is set at $5,200,000 for fiscal years 2001 through 2003. The Act will take effect 180 days after enactment and will not apply to rules published 3 years after the effective date.
